questionContent.body: At the database level, how can we ensure that no patient is inserted with a NULL name?

https://quicktest-prod-media.s3.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/questions/images/1752744389785496770_ChatGPT%20Image%20Jul%2017%2C%202025%20at%2002_35_35%20PM.png?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Credential=AKIA4V756IAS5555JRNY%2F20250802%2Fap-south-1%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Date=20250802T143606Z&X-Amz-Expires=604800&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host&x-id=GetObject&X-Amz-Signature=379854639b22ec1e3a8d2b1ffaa7e9110eb3686f747517b476e53048b9ee6fa2

questionOptions.body: Add a unique constraint to the name column
Use a NOT NULL constraint on name column in Patient table

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
ðŸ”´ Explanation:

â†’ To ensure data integrity, a NOT NULL constraint must be applied on the name column in the Patient table. This prevents insertion of records without a name.

questionContent.body: Which SQL query retrieves patients who have consulted more than one doctor?

https://quicktest-prod-media.s3.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/questions/images/1752744224102756807_ChatGPT%20Image%20Jul%2017%2C%202025%20at%2002_35_35%20PM.png?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Credential=AKIA4V756IAS5555JRNY%2F20250802%2Fap-south-1%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Date=20250802T143606Z&X-Amz-Expires=604800&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host&x-id=GetObject&X-Amz-Signature=b8534e48fbf1a4a98b4611b0761febcc541f241273a1bd90a720e3f6df8275a0

questionOptions.body:
SELECT P.name

FROM Patient P

JOIN Visits V ON P.patient_id = V.patient_id

GROUP BY P.name

HAVING COUNT(*) > 1;

SELECT P.name

FROM Patient P

WHERE P.patient_id IN (

SELECT patient_id

FROM Visits

GROUP BY patient_id

HAVING COUNT(DISTINCT doctor_id) > 1

);

SELECT P.name

FROM Patient P

JOIN Visits V ON P.patient_id = V.patient_id

GROUP BY P.patient_id, P.name

HAVING COUNT(DISTINCT V.doctor_id) > 1;

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
ðŸ”´ Explanation:

â†’ We're counting how many distinct doctors each patient has seen. So we use GROUP BY patient_id, and filter with HAVING COUNT(DISTINCT doctor_id) > 1.

questionContent.body: How would you design a query to retrieve names of doctors who have not had any visits recorded yet

questionOptions.body: SELECT name FROM Doctor WHERE doctor_id IS NULL;

SELECT D.name FROM Doctor D

JOIN Visits V ON D.doctor_id = V.doctor_id;

SELECT D.name

FROM Doctor D

LEFT JOIN Visits V ON D.doctor_id = V.doctor_id

WHERE V.visit_id IS NULL;
SELECT name FROM Visits WHERE doctor_id NOT IN Doctor;

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
ðŸ”´ Explanation:

â†’ A LEFT JOIN returns all doctors, even those with no visits. The WHERE V.visit_id IS NULL filters out those who never had any visits. Classic anti-join pattern

questionContent.body: What normalization problem may arise if department_name is stored directly in the Doctor table instead of using dept_id?

https://quicktest-prod-media.s3.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/questions/images/1752743200828036386_ChatGPT%20Image%20Jul%2017%2C%202025%20at%2002_35_35%20PM.png?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Credential=AKIA4V756IAS5555JRNY%2F20250802%2Fap-south-1%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Date=20250802T143607Z&X-Amz-Expires=604800&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host&x-id=GetObject&X-Amz-Signature=b49f8dbf9734e90dc76609d1f38a2a1a2d8b6074d76cce379679aba2d4fa0098

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
ðŸ”´ Explanation:

â†’ doctor_id â†’ dept_id â†’ dept_name

If dept_name is stored in Doctor, it becomes transitively dependent on doctor_id. This violates 3NF, since non-prime attribute (dept_name) depends on another non-prime attribute (dept_id).

questionContent.body: What is the transitive dependency if we store publisher_address in Book?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The attribute publisher_address does not directly depend on the primary key book_id, but rather on publisher, which depends on book_id. This forms a transitive dependency

questionContent.body: What normal form is violated by storing publisher_address in Book table?

https://quicktest-prod-media.s3.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/questions/images/1752738089733212403_ChatGPT%20Image%20Jul%2017%2C%202025%20at%2012_57_18%20PM.png?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Credential=AKIA4V756IAS5555JRNY%2F20250802%2Fap-south-1%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Date=20250802T143607Z&X-Amz-Expires=604800&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host&x-id=GetObject&X-Amz-Signature=26009d138f09f20a59a26480dade3ccd5153059e4c483e86c8ab8244bd9898d3

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
ðŸ”´ Explanation:

â†’ 3NF is violated because publisher_address has a transitive dependency through another non-key attribute (publisher). It should be moved to a separate Publisher table to preserve 3NF.

questionContent.body: Which SQL query will return the list of books that are currently issued (i.e., books that have not been returned yet)?

https://quicktest-prod-media.s3.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/questions/images/1752737941763213584_ChatGPT%20Image%20Jul%2017%2C%202025%20at%2012_57_18%20PM.png?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Credential=AKIA4V756IAS5555JRNY%2F20250802%2Fap-south-1%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Date=20250802T143607Z&X-Amz-Expires=604800&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host&x-id=GetObject&X-Amz-Signature=f05357c65bba9e6b443d3146ddcacf7ff73b9d041feca9e47aa3ee9b4ad7adce

questionOptions.body:
SELECT B.title

FROM Book B

JOIN Member M ON B.book_id = M.member_id

WHERE B.return_date IS NULL;

SELECT B.title

FROM Book B

JOIN Issue I ON B.book_id = I.book_id

WHERE I.return_date IS NULL;

SELECT title

FROM Issue

WHERE return_date IS NOT NULL;

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
ðŸ”´ Explanation:

â†’ Option (c) is correct because it correctly joins the Book and Issue tables using book_id, and filters records where return_date IS NULL, meaning the book has not been returned yet.

Other options either reference wrong tables or filter the wrong condition (IS NOT NULL).

questionContent.body: Which of the following can be a primary key for the Issue table?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
ðŸ”´ Explanation:

â†’ issue_id is the unique identifier for each issue transaction, so it's the best choice for a primary key. Other fields are not unique by themselves.

questionContent.body: Which relationship exists between Member and Book through Issue?

https://quicktest-prod-media.s3.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/questions/images/1752737315870187004_ChatGPT%20Image%20Jul%2017%2C%202025%20at%2012_57_18%20PM.png?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Credential=AKIA4V756IAS5555JRNY%2F20250802%2Fap-south-1%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Date=20250802T143608Z&X-Amz-Expires=604800&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host&x-id=GetObject&X-Amz-Signature=ac62e5587f5e1f1137290743945d9c887e1fc31218e1027c7d34ec67a53e9ec8

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
ðŸ”´ Explanation:

â†’ A single member can issue multiple books, and the same book can be issued to multiple members at different times. This is a many-to-many (M:N) relationship, implemented through the Issue table.

questionContent.body: ER Diagram 1: University Enrollment System

What is the type of relationship between Student and Course?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Explanation:

â†’ A student can enroll in multiple courses, and each course can have multiple students, so this is a many-to-manyrelationship.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a candidate key in the Enrollment table?

https://quicktest-prod-media.s3.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/questions/images/1752736273814013519_ChatGPT%20Image%20Jul%2017%2C%202025%20at%2012_00_22%20PM.png?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Credential=AKIA4V756IAS5555JRNY%2F20250802%2Fap-south-1%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Date=20250802T143608Z&X-Amz-Expires=604800&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host&x-id=GetObject&X-Amz-Signature=ada6c278c9658aceb9f866eef865818bd5e0f4aa7a636e2323edf000571d15bb

solution.name: Solution 1

ðŸ”´ Explanation:

â†’ Since multiple students can enroll in the same course and vice versa, only the combination (student_id, course_id)uniquely identifies each record â€” hence it's a composite candidate key.

questionContent.body: Which SQL query fetches names of students enrolled in any course from the 'CSE' department?

https://quicktest-prod-media.s3.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/questions/images/1752735977234783666_ChatGPT%20Image%20Jul%2017%2C%202025%20at%2012_00_22%20PM.png?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Credential=AKIA4V756IAS5555JRNY%2F20250802%2Fap-south-1%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Date=20250802T143608Z&X-Amz-Expires=604800&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host&x-id=GetObject&X-Amz-Signature=a1a1d44c7e5718ea054875310dee1cf7c0a3299519aa5d7a04faced30d430331

questionOptions.body:
SELECT S.name

FROM Student S

JOIN Department D ON S.department_id = D.department_id

WHERE D.dept_name = 'CSE';

SELECT S.name

FROM Student S

JOIN Enrollment E ON S.student_id = E.student_id

JOIN Course C ON E.course_id = C.course_id

JOIN Department D ON C.dept_id = D.department_id

WHERE D.dept_name = 'CSE';

SELECT S.name

FROM Student S

JOIN Course C ON S.student_id = C.course_id

WHERE C.dept_id = 'CSE';

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
ðŸ”´ Explanation:

â†’ Only option (c) correctly performs joins across Student â†’ Enrollment â†’ Course â†’ Department, and filters where dept_name = 'CSE'. All others miss the correct joins or filter.

questionContent.body: Which normal form is violated if multiple phone numbers are stored in one column?

https://quicktest-prod-media.s3.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/questions/images/1752735817810943271_ChatGPT%20Image%20Jul%2017%2C%202025%20at%2012_00_22%20PM.png?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Credential=AKIA4V756IAS5555JRNY%2F20250802%2Fap-south-1%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Date=20250802T143609Z&X-Amz-Expires=604800&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host&x-id=GetObject&X-Amz-Signature=a53c2ec83279dbf77c03e18244b068c7df43e42c94f0f51cb58d7cfbdb65ee6d

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
ðŸ”´ Explanation:

â†’ 1NF is violated because storing multiple phone numbers in one column breaks the rule of atomicity â€” each field should store only one value.

questionContent.body: Which attribute is multi-valued in Student?

solution.name: Solution 1

â†’ A student can have more than one phone number, so phone_number is a multi-valued attribute, violating 1NF if not handled properly.

questionContent.body: What will be the result of an INNER JOIN if there is no matching row in the second table?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer: B


Explanation: INNER JOIN only returns rows with matching values in both tables.

questionContent.body: Which isolation level avoids dirty reads but may allow non-repeatable reads and phantoms?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer: B

Explanation: Read Committed prevents dirty reads but not non-repeatable reads or phantoms.

questionContent.body: Phantom read occurs when:

questionOptions.body: A new row is added between reads in the same transaction

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
answer: B

Explanation: Phantom reads occur when new rows appear due to inserts by other transactions between reads.

questionContent.body: Which anomaly is most likely to occur in a poorly normalized table?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer: C

Explanation: Poor normalization leads to anomalies like update, insert, and delete anomalies

questionContent.body: In ER modeling, which type of key can consist of multiple attributes?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer: C

Explanation: Composite key is a combination of two or more attributes to uniquely identify a record.

questionContent.body: Which index type stores a copy of all selected columns and doesn't reference the table?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer: C

Explanation: Covering index stores all necessary columns to answer a query without accessing the base table.

questionContent.body: ï»¿Which of the following ACID properties ensures that the database remains consistent before and after a transaction?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Explanation: Consistency ensures integrity constraints are maintained before and after transaction execution.

questionContent.body: Denormalization is generally used to:

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer: C

Explanation: Denormalization is often used for performance optimization by introducing controlled redundancy.

questionContent.body: Which normal form removes partial dependency?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer: B

Explanation: 2NF removes partial dependencies (i.e., non-prime attribute depending on part of a composite key).

questionContent.body: What is a dirty read in the context of transactions?

questionOptions.body: Reading data without a WHERE clause

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer: B

Explanation: Dirty read happens when a transaction reads data written by another uncommitted transaction.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is an example of a lost update problem?

questionOptions.body: Two users reading the same data simultaneously
A transaction overwriting another transactionâ€™s update without checking

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer: D

Explanation: Lost update occurs when two transactions update the same data concurrently and one update overwrites

questionContent.body: What process does DHCP use to assign IPs?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Explanation:


DHCP uses DORA: Discover, Offer, Request, Acknowledge â€” to dynamically assign IPs.

questionContent.body: What does a CNAME record do?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Explanation:


CNAME creates aliases, so multiple domain names can point to one actual domain.

questionContent.body: Which DNS record maps a domain to an IP?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A (Address) records resolve domain names to IPv4 addresses.

questionContent.body: Why is HTTPS more secure than HTTP?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Explanation:


HTTPS encrypts data using SSL/TLS, protecting it from eavesdropping and tampering.

questionContent.body: Which protocol provides sequencing of packets?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Explanation:


TCP tracks packet order using sequence numbers to ensure proper data reassembly.

questionContent.body: What does nslookup google.com 8.8.8.8 do?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The second argument in nslookup specifies the DNS server to use for resolving the domain.

questionContent.body: Which ipconfig option releases the current DHCP lease?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: ipconfig /release sends a DHCPRELEASE to the server, freeing the IP address. /renew requests a new one.

questionContent.body: What does the command netstat -an display?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Explanation:

-a shows all connections/listening ports, -n displays IP addresses and ports numerically (no DNS names).

questionContent.body: What mechanism does traceroute use to identify each hop in a path?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Explanation:


Traceroute sends packets with increasing TTL (Time To Live). Each router along the path decreases TTL by 1 and replies when it hits zero, revealing the path hop by hop.

questionContent.body: Which layer of the OSI model does the ping utility primarily test?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Explanation:


Ping uses the ICMP protocol, which operates at the Network Layer (Layer 3) to check if a host is reachable.

questionContent.body: Thrashing in an operating system occurs when:

questionOptions.body: Too many processes are waiting in the ready queue.
The system spends more time swapping pages than executing processes.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: C) The system spends more time swapping pages than executing processes.


ðŸ’¡ Explanation: Thrashing reduces CPU utilization due to excessive paging.

questionContent.body: Internal fragmentation occurs when:

questionOptions.body: There is not enough total memory but free spaces are non-contiguous.
Allocated memory block is larger than the requested memory.
Processes are too large to fit into memory.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: B) Allocated memory block is larger than the requested memory.


ðŸ’¡ Explanation: Unused space inside an allocated block is internal fragmentation.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a safe state in deadlock avoidance?

questionOptions.body: All processes can finish without circular wait.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: B) All processes can finish without circular wait.


ðŸ’¡ Explanation: In a safe state, there's at least one sequence of execution where every process completes.

questionContent.body: When a process is in the Ready state, it means:

questionOptions.body: It is ready to run and waiting to be assigned to a CPU.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: C) It is ready to run and waiting to be assigned to a CPU.


ðŸ’¡ Explanation: Ready state = loaded in memory and waiting for CPU time.

questionContent.body: For the reference string: 7, 0, 1, 2, 0, 3, 0, 4, 2, 3, and 3 page frames, how many page faults occur using LRU?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: A) 8


ðŸ’¡ Explanation: Use LRU policy simulation. Least Recently Used page is replaced when a new page needs space.

questionContent.body:
Consider the following pseudocode using a binary semaphore S initialized to 1:

wait(S);

critical section;

signal(S);

Which of the following problems does this solve?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: B) Race condition


ðŸ’¡ Explanation: The wait-signal mechanism ensures mutual exclusion, preventing race conditions in critical sections.

questionContent.body: In a demand paging system, what happens when a page fault occurs?

questionOptions.body: OS suspends the process and frees memory.
OS loads the required page from secondary memory to main memory.
OS skips the instruction causing the fault.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: C) OS loads the required page from secondary memory to main memory.


ðŸ’¡ Explanation: A page fault triggers the OS to fetch the missing page from disk.

questionContent.body: In Priority Scheduling, what is aging used for?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: B) To prevent starvation of low-priority processes


ðŸ’¡ Explanation: Aging gradually increases priority of waiting processes.

questionContent.body: When a thread calls join() on another thread, what happens?

questionOptions.body: It makes the current thread wait until the other thread finishes.
It sends a signal to the thread to pause.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: B) It makes the current thread wait until the other thread finishes.


ðŸ’¡ Explanation:join() is used for synchronization between threads.

questionContent.body: Which of the following statements is true?

questionOptions.body: Paging makes memory access slower due to fragmentation.
Paging uses fixed-size pages; segmentation uses variable-size segments.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: D) Paging uses fixed-size pages; segmentation uses variable-size segments.


ðŸ’¡ Explanation: Paging = fixed-size â†’ no external fragmentation; Segmentation = logical division â†’ variable-size.

questionContent.body: In a Multilevel Queue Scheduling, which of the following is true?

questionOptions.body: All processes can freely move between queues.
Each queue has its own scheduling algorithm.
Round Robin is mandatory for all queues.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: B) Each queue has its own scheduling algorithm.


ðŸ’¡ Explanation: Multilevel queues are separated by priority or type and can use different algorithms (e.g., RR for foreground, FCFS for background).

questionContent.body: Which strategy can be used to prevent deadlocks by ensuring that the system is always in a safe state?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: A) Banker's algorithm


ðŸ’¡ Explanation: Banker's algorithm checks if resource allocation keeps system in a safe state.

questionContent.body: In Petersonâ€™s solution, which variables are used to achieve mutual exclusion?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: C) both flag[ ] and turn


ðŸ’¡ Explanation: Petersonâ€™s solution uses flag[i] and turn for mutual exclusion in two-process systems.

questionContent.body: For reference string: 1, 2, 3, 4, 1, 2, 5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 with 3 page frames, what is the number of page faults using FIFO?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: A) 9

questionContent.body: A system uses paging with 4 KB page size and 32-bit logical address space. How many pages are there in the logical address space?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: B) 2^20


ðŸ’¡ Explanation:



  • Page size = 2^12



  • Logical address space = 2^32



  • Pages = 2^32 / 2^12 = 2^20

questionContent.body: Which of the following conditions is not necessary for deadlock?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: D) Preemption


ðŸ’¡ Explanation:Preemption prevents deadlock; deadlock requires non-preemption.

questionContent.body: Given processes with arrival time = 0, and burst times: P1=8, P2=4, P3=2. Using Shortest Job First (non-preemptive), what is the average waiting time?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: B) 4.33 ms


ðŸ’¡ Explanation:



  • Order: P3 â†’ P2 â†’ P1



  • Waiting: P3=0, P2=2, P1=6



  • Avg = (0+2+6)/3 = 8/3 â‰ˆ 4.33

questionContent.body: Which of the following is true regarding threads?

questionOptions.body: Threads are more expensive to create than processes.
Threads within the same process share code, data, and heap.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: C) Threads within the same process share code, data, and heap.


ðŸ’¡ Explanation: Threads share the memory of their parent process, making context switch faster.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is not a valid file operation provided by most file systems?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: C) Fork


ðŸ’¡ Explanation:fork() is a process creation system call, not a file operation.

questionContent.body: In indexed file allocation, what is the maximum number of disk blocks a file can occupy if each index block can store pointers to 256 blocks and each file can have one index block?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Answer: B) 256


ðŸ’¡ Explanation: One index block points to 256 data blocks, and each file has one such index block

questionContent.body: Which of the following is true about BCNF but not necessarily true about 3NF?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer: âœ… A) Every determinant is a candidate key

Explanation:

BCNF is a stricter version of 3NF. It requires that every determinant (LHS of FD) must be a candidate key.


3NF allows a determinant to be a non-key if the RHS is a prime attribute.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a violation of Third Normal Form (3NF)?

questionOptions.body: A â†’ B and B â†’ C, hence A â†’ C
A â†’ B where B is not a key
Every non-prime attribute is transitively dependent on key
A â†’ C, where C is a prime attribute

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer: âœ… C) Every non-prime attribute is transitively dependent on key

Explanation:


In 3NF, all transitive dependencies must be removed. That means no non-prime attribute should be transitively dependent on the primary key.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is true for a relation in 2NF?

questionOptions.body: It must be in 1NF and have no transitive dependencies
It must be in 1NF and every non-prime attribute fully functionally dependent on the primary key
It must be in 1NF and each attribute is atomic
It must be in 1NF and all attributes functionally depend on each other

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer: âœ… B) It must be in 1NF and every non-prime attribute fully functionally dependent on the primary key

Explanation:


2NF = 1NF + No partial dependencies (i.e., non-prime attributes should not depend on part of a composite key).

questionContent.body: Which of the following violates First Normal Form (1NF)?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer: âœ… B) Repeating groups in a column

Explanation:


1NF requires atomic (indivisible) values. If a column contains a list or set of values (e.g., multiple phone numbers in one field), it violates 1NF.

questionContent.body: Which of the following anomalies is most likely to occur in an unnormalized relation with repeated groups?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer: âœ… D) All of the above


Explanation:


Unnormalized relations (with multi-valued/repeating groups) can cause:



  • Insertion Anomaly: Cannot insert data unless all columns have values.



  • Deletion Anomaly: Deleting one data item may remove related data.



  • Update Anomaly: Repeating data must be updated in multiple places.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a transitive dependency?

questionOptions.body: A â†’ B, B â†’ C implies A â†’ C
A â†’ B and B is a key
C â†’ A and A â†’ B

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Correct Answer: A

Explanation: A transitive dependency occurs when A â†’ B and B â†’ C, so A â†’ C indirectly. This is an undesirable situation in 3NF.

questionContent.body: Consider a relation R(A, B, C, D) with dependencies: A â†’ B, B â†’ C, C â†’ D. Which of the following is a correct functional dependency?

questionOptions.body: A â†’ B, A â†’ C, A â†’ D

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Correct Answer: D


Explanation: From A â†’ B and B â†’ C and C â†’ D, we can derive:



  • A â†’ C (via B),



  • A â†’ D (via B and C),

  • So all three are correct and transitive dependencies.

questionContent.body: In a table, EmpID â†’ DeptID and DeptID â†’ DeptName, What kind of dependency is EmpID â†’ DeptName?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Since EmpID â†’ DeptID and DeptID â†’ DeptName,


by transitivity: EmpID â†’ DeptName, making it a transitive dependency.

questionContent.body: Which of the following violates 3rd Normal Form (3NF)?

questionOptions.body: Every non-prime attribute depends only on the key
A transitive dependency exists on a non-key attribute
Every non-key attribute is functionally dependent on a part of a candidate key
Each table has only one candidate key

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 3NF is violated if a transitive dependency exists on a non-prime attribute (an attribute not part of any candidate key). This can lead to data anomalies.

questionContent.body: What does a functional dependency A â†’ B mean?

questionOptions.body: B is a primary key of A

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
âœ… Correct Answer: B

Explanation: A â†’ B means that the value of attribute A uniquely determines attribute B. That is, if two tuples have the same A value, they must have the same B value.

questionContent.body: Anomalies are primarily caused by:

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Anomalies arise when data is not properly normalized, causing redundancy and dependency issues in the table.

questionContent.body: A deletion anomaly occurs when:

questionOptions.body: Deleting a row causes loss of needed data

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: If deleting a row removes data that is still needed (e.g., losing customer info when removing an order), itâ€™s a deletion anomaly.

questionContent.body: When updating one piece of information requires multiple updates across rows, it is called:

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Update anomaly happens when the same piece of data is duplicated in multiple rows, and updating it requires multiple operations to avoid inconsistency.

questionContent.body: An insertion anomaly occurs when:

questionOptions.body: You cannot insert data without other unrelated data

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Insertion anomalies occur when a row cannot be added to the database without the presence of some other data â€” often because of improper design.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is NOT a type of anomaly in unnormalized relations?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Join anomaly is not typically listed as one of the three main anomalies. The main anomalies due to unnormalized data are: insertion, deletion, and update anomalies.
